content.text: A block of mass \(12\mathrm{kg}\) is being pulled by a rope up a rough plane. The plane is inclined at an angle of \(20^{\circ}\) above the horizontal. The rope pulling the block is parallel to a line of greatest slope of the plane. The coefficient of friction between the block and the plane is 0.4. The acceleration of the block is \(2\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{-2}\).
Find the tension in the rope.

Three coplanar forces of magnitudes \(P\mathrm{N}\), \(5\mathrm{N}\) and \(10\mathrm{N}\) act at a point \(O\), as shown in the diagram. The resultant of the three forces has magnitude \(Q\mathrm{N}\) and acts in a direction perpendicular to the force of magnitude \(P\mathrm{N}\).
Find the value of \(P\) and the value of \(Q\).

The diagram shows the velocity-time graph of the motion of a cyclist. The graph consists of three straight line segments. The cyclist passes a point \(O\) with speed \(3\mathrm{ms}^{-1}\) and then accelerates for \(10\mathrm{s}\) with constant acceleration \(0.5\mathrm{ms}^{-2}\). He then travels at constant speed for \(30\mathrm{s}\) before decelerating, coming to rest at point \(P\), covering a distance of \(80\mathrm{m}\) whilst decelerating.
Find the total time taken for the journey from \(O\) to \(P\).
On the given axes, sketch a displacement-time graph for the cyclist's journey from \(O\) to \(P\), showing on your graph the distances travelled after 10s and 40s.
A lorry of mass \(18000\mathrm{kg}\) is travelling along a straight road.
On a horizontal section of the road, the power of the lorry's engine is constant. There is a constant resistance to motion of \(1600\mathrm{N}\).
The steady speed which the lorry can maintain with the engine working at power \(P\mathrm{W}\) is \(30\mathrm{ms}^{-1}\).
Find the value of \(P\).
At an instant when the speed of the lorry is \(16\mathrm{ms}^{-1}\), its engine is working at a power of \(40\mathrm{kW}\). Find the acceleration of the lorry at this instant.

When the lorry has reached a speed of \(20\mathrm{ms}^{-1}\), it begins to ascend a section of road inclined at an angle \(\alpha^{\circ}\) to the horizontal. The engine now works at a power of \(120\mathrm{kW}\). There is no change in the lorry's speed as it ascends the hill. The constant resistance to motion remains \(1600\mathrm{N}\).
Find the value of \(\alpha\).
When a particle \(P\) of mass \(m\mathrm{kg}\) has speed \(u\mathrm{ms}^{-1}\), its momentum is \(4\mathrm{Ns}\) and its kinetic energy is \(16\mathrm{J}\).
Find the value of \(m\) and the value of \(u\).

\(P\) is now projected on a smooth horizontal surface with speed \(v\mathrm{ms}^{-1}\) directly towards a particle \(Q\) of mass \(1.25\mathrm{kg}\) which is stationary. After \(P\) and \(Q\) collide, the velocity of \(P\) is \(w\mathrm{ms}^{-1}\) and the velocity of \(Q\) is \(2w\mathrm{ms}^{-1}\). The loss of kinetic energy in the collision is \(25\mathrm{J}\).
Find the value of \(v\) and the value of \(w\).

Two particles, \(P\) and \(Q\), of masses \(0.3\mathrm{kg}\) and \(0.6\mathrm{kg}\) respectively, are attached to the ends of a light inextensible string. The string passes over a smooth pulley fixed at a point \(B\) where the inclined planes \(AB\) and \(BC\) meet. \(P\) lies on the smooth plane \(AB\) which is inclined at an angle \(\theta^{\circ}\) to the horizontal where \(\sin\theta^{\circ} = 0.4\). \(Q\) lies on the plane \(BC\) which is inclined at \(30^{\circ}\) to the horizontal. The string is taut and the particles can move on lines of greatest slope of the two planes (see diagram). The particles are released from rest.
It is given that the plane \(BC\) is smooth.
Find the tension in the string and the acceleration of \(Q\).

It is given instead that the plane \(BC\) is rough. The work done against the frictional force when \(Q\) moves \(2\mathrm{m}\) down the plane is \(1.8\mathrm{J}\). You should assume that \(P\) does not reach the pulley and that \(Q\) does not reach \(C\).
Use an energy method to find the speed of \(Q\) when it has moved \(2\mathrm{m}\) down the plane.

A particle \(X\) moves along a straight track, starting from a point \(O\) at time \(t = 0\). The displacement of \(X\) from \(O\) at time \(t\mathrm{s}\) is \(s\mathrm{m}\), where \(s = 3t^{\frac{3}{2}} - 6t\).
Find the time at which \(X\) is instantaneously at rest, and hence find the total distance travelled by \(X\) between \(t = 0\) and \(t = 16\).

A second particle \(Y\) moves along another straight track, starting from a point \(P\) at time \(t = 0\). The acceleration of \(Y\) at time \(t\mathrm{s}\) is \(a\mathrm{ms}^{-2}\), where \(a = 0.8 - 0.6t\). The velocity of \(Y\) when it leaves \(P\) is \(7.5\mathrm{ms}^{-1}\).
When the velocity of \(Y\) is \(-9.6\mathrm{ms}^{-1}\), show that the displacement of \(X\) from \(O\) is equal to the displacement of \(Y\) from \(P\).
